title-group.article-title: Prediction of bending rigidity for laminated weft knitted fabric with adhesive interlining

abstract.p: The purpose of this study is to predict bending rigidity of laminated weft knitted fabric using three prediction methods and to determine their suitability for predicting. The methods are as follows: Method 1: the laminate theory using bending rigidities and thicknesses of components, Method 2: an equation derived from the laminate theory taken into account the tensile and in-plane compressive moduli of components, Method 3: an equation in consideration of the position of the neutral axis in bending on a face fabric. Six weft knitted fabrics and ten adhesive interlinings, sixty laminated composites with those combinations were used. Tensile properties and bending rigidities, thicknesses of samples were measured. The other necessary parameters for the prediction were obtained by additional experiments and calculation. It was found that the results by Method 3 showed the closest agreements with experimental ones. It is due to the relative positions of the neutral axes for all knitted fabric samples are not in the centroid. It became clear that the position must be taken into account for calculating bending rigidities of laminated knitted fabric with adhesive interlining.

body.p: Knitted fabrics are used for various garments such as sweaters, underwear, hosiery, and baby blankets because of their soft, stretchy, and drapery properties. A trend toward a casual lifestyle is reflected in knitted garments. As this trend also affects the formal dress style, people would like to wear softer and more stretchy garments even when wearing suits. Thus, suits and other outerwear made of knitted fabrics have appeared on the market.

For manufacturing garments, mechanical properties of fabrics are controlled using subsidiary materials because of the insufficient stiffness of a face fabric. An adhesive interlining using a thermoplastic resin is taken as a representative example. Adhesive interlinings are used for knitted fabrics as well as for woven fabrics to give a suitable appearance and stability to garments.

In previous studies,1–3 the prediction of bending rigidity for a laminated fabric with a woven fabric and adhesive interlining was investigated using three prediction methods, as shown below. It became clear that changes in the mechanical properties of components induced by the pressing process need to be considered in laminate theory.1 It was also found that bending rigidities of laminated fabrics can be predicted using tensile and in-plane compressive moduli of components.2 For a more precise prediction of bending rigidities, only the placements of neutral axes needed to be taken into account for some fabrics.3 From these results, it was possible to predict bending rigidity of a laminated fabric with a woven fabric and an adhesive interlining. However, these predictions were mainly carried out with woven fabrics for face fabrics. The tensile and in-plane compressive properties of knitted fabrics have not been investigated yet. Thus, it is uncertain if these methods will be suitable for knitted fabrics because their structures and mechanical properties are different to those of woven fabrics.

Gibson and Postle4 investigated the mechanical properties of a wide range of commercially produced outerwear fabrics, woven fabrics, double-knits, and warp-knits in terms of the elastic and frictional resistance to bending and shear deformations. They reported that the different bending properties depended on different fabric structures. Alimaa et al.5 also investigated the bending properties of a series of plain and rib weft-knitted structures, and carried out theoretical analyses on the effects of yarn bending properties and fabric structure on the bending rigidity. However, these studies did not investigate laminated knitted fabrics.

Some studies were carried out to predict the bending rigidity of laminated knitted fabrics. Dawes and Owen6 investigated the prediction of bending rigidity for a composite with one knitted fabric taking into account the tensile and in-plane compressive moduli. However, this showed unsatisfactory prediction results with large prediction errors. Shishoo et al.7 also introduced regression equations for the bending rigidity of laminated knitted fabrics. They also tested one knitted fabric sample and did not consider the mechanical properties of knitted fabrics. Thus, a more precise prediction of the bending rigidity of laminated knitted fabric is necessary.

Therefore, our aim in this study is to investigate the validity of these prediction methods of bending rigidity for laminated knitted fabrics, and to determine the most suitable ones. By investigating the prediction method for knitted fabrics, selecting the suitable adhesive interlining for knitted fabrics will be possible without testing the laminating fabrics in every case.

sec.title: Method 1
sec.p:
The laminate theory for elastic continua can be basically used to predict the bending rigidity of laminated fabric.1 The equation is given by (1)B12=3B1B2(h1+h2)2(B1h22+B2h12)+B1+B2 where h1 and h2 are the thicknesses of adhesive interlining and face fabric as shown in Figure 1. B1 and B2 are the bending rigidities of adhesive interlining and face fabric. B12 is the bending rigidity of laminated fabric with adhesive interlining. The method using equation (1) is denoted as Method 1. Figure 1.
Structure of laminated fabric.

sec.title: Method 2
sec.p: A fabric is not an elastic continuum, so the tensile and in-plane compressive moduli, Et and Ec, may be different from the elastic modulus in bending, Eb. Assuming that Eb, Et, and Ec of both fabrics are independent and the neutral axes in bending are in the centroid of each fabric, equation (1) can be expressed with in-plane compressive and tensile moduli as follows2 (2)B12=T1T2T1+T2(h1+h22)2+B1+B2 where T1 and T2 are apparent in-plane compressive modulus and apparent tensile modulus, respectively, and are assumed as constants. The apparent tensile modulus, T2, can be obtained by a tensile test. To obtain the apparent in-plane compressive modulus, T1, equation (3) was proposed (3)T1=-T2{B12-(B1+B2)}B12-(B1+B2)-T2(h1+h22)2 T1 can be obtained by a bending test of a combination of an adhesive interlining and a specific fabric, and then we can predict the bending rigidity of laminates with the interlining and other fabrics by equations (2) and (3). The method using these equations is denoted as Method 2.

sec.title: Method 3
sec.p: The relative position of the neutral axis in bending, Y2, for a face fabric was taken into account to predict the bending rigidity of a laminated fabric far more precisely.3 The prediction equation in consideration of Y2 is given by (4)B12=T2T1(h1+2Y2h2)(h2+h1)4(T1+T2)+B1+B2

Equation (5) can be used to obtain Y2. (5)Y2=2(B12-B1-B2)h2(h1+h2)(1T2+1T1)-h12h2 Y2 can be obtained by a bending test of a combination of a fabric and an adhesive interlining, and then we can predict the bending rigidity of laminates with fabric and other interlinings. The method using Equations (4) and (5) is denoted as Method 3.

sec.title: Experimental details
sec.p: Experiments were carried out to confirm the validity of the three prediction methods for the bending rigidity of laminated knitted fabrics. Adhesive interlinings were used on the inside of clothing and the face fabric was on the outside of the arc of bending, as shown in Figure 1. Weft-knitted fabrics having different structures, and adhesive interlinings and laminated fabrics with these combinations were prepared as experimental samples.

sec.title: Obtaining parameters for the prediction methods
sec.p: Bending rigidities of all the samples were measured on warp and weft and on wale and course directions, respectively, using a KES-FB2 pure bending tester.8 The thickness of each sample was measured using a KES-FB3 compression tester at 49 Pa load in the thickness direction. The load from 0 to about 2.5% of elongation from the load–elongation curve obtained with the by KES-FB1 tensile tester, on warp and weft and on wale and course directions, respectively, was used to calculate the T2 for each face fabric. T1 can be obtained when the neutral axes in bending of the components are assumed to be in the centroids of both components. However, it is uncertain that the neutral axes of knitted fabric samples pass through the centroids of the cross section. The centroids are the centers of each cross section. Thus, we carried out the experiments for a combination of specific face fabrics (N1 and N2) and interlining, for which neutral axes in bending can be assumed to lie in the centroid.2 With the obtained values, T1 was calculated using equation (3). Then Y2 values for face fabrics were calculated using equation (5).

Every test was carried out under standardized conditions (20 ± 1℃ and 65 ± 5% relative humidity). All samples were preconditioned under these standardized conditions for 24 hours. Every test was conducted on five samples and the averages were used.

The bending rigidities of other laminated fabrics bonded with the face fabrics and different interlinings were predicted using Methods 1, 2, and 3. Those results were compared with the experimental data.

sec.title: Experimental samples
sec.p:
The sample specifications are shown in Tables 1, 2, and 3. Six weft-knitted fabrics were used for face fabrics. Two twill fabrics (N1 and N2, in which Y2 can be assumed to lie in the centroid2) were used for face fabrics to obtain T1 of the adhesive interlinings. Also, ten adhesive interlinings usually found in knitted fabrics in the market were used. Sixty combinations of laminated fabrics were constructed and examined. These were polyester plain fabrics and the adhesive agent was polyamide of dot printing type. Laminating interlining to the face fabric was done automatically using a press machine (Kobe Denki Kogyosyo, BP-V4812D). Adhesive interlining was put on the face fabric and both were inserted in the press machine. The press machine was a flat type press machine which had one heating side and another non heating side. The interlining side was heated. After pressing both fabrics, these were bonded. The bonding conditions were 150℃, under 29.4 kPa load, and a 10 s pressing time. Table 1.

sec.title: Pressed samples
sec.p: The mechanical properties of woven fabrics and adhesive interlinings changed after the pressing procedure for laminating. This must be considered when predicting the bending rigidity of laminated fabrics.1 However, the changes in bending rigidities and thicknesses of knitted fabric are unclear. Thus, the changes in mechanical properties of knitted fabrics caused by pressing were also investigated. To investigate these, samples pressed alone under the same press conditions of laminating were prepared. These mechanical properties were measured and compared to those of the samples before pressing. The method is as follows: face fabric samples were pressed using the press machine under the same conditions as for bonding interlining. For adhesive interlinings, polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) film (NITTO, No.900, 0.05 × 300 mm) was prepared. Adhesive interlinings were bonded to PTFE films and then PTFE films were removed from the adhesive interlinings. The samples pressed alone are referred to as ‘pressed samples’. Face fabric and adhesive interlining pressed alone are referred to as ‘pressed face fabric’ and ‘pressed adhesive interlining’.

sec.title: Results and discussions
sec.p:
The bending rigidities of knitted fabric before and after pressing are shown in Figure 2. The bending rigidities of most knitted fabrics decreased after pressing in both wale and course directions by about 12%. The thicknesses of knitted fabrics before and after pressing are shown in Figure 3. After pressing, the thicknesses of most samples, except KN4, decreased about 16%. Therefore, these results show that the bending rigidity and thickness of knitted fabrics changed after pressing. The change rates in thickness and bending rigidity were about 6% and 3% for woven fabrics.1 The differences in bending rigidity and thickness for knitted fabrics between before pressing and after pressing were larger than those of woven fabrics. This is due to the structures of knitted fabrics, which have larger spaces between yarns than those of woven fabrics. Figure 2.
Bending rigidities of knitted fabrics in the (a) wale direction and (b) course direction.
Figure 3.
Thicknesses of knitted fabrics before and after pressing.

sec.title: Method 1
sec.p:
Assuming the components as elastic continua, conventional laminate theory was used in Method 1. The bending rigidities of laminated fabrics were predicted using Method 1 with the obtained values of pressed samples. A comparison of the predicted bending rigidities and experimental ones is shown in Figure 4. The mean absolute percentage errors (MAPEs) between calculated and experimental bending rigidities are shown in Table 5. In the results of experimental bending rigidities, bending rigidities of some samples were over 0.6 cNi·cm2/cm and those of some samples were under 0.6 cN·cm2/cm. The samples of bending rigidities over 0.6 cN·cm2/cm are all laminated knitted fabric with milano rib samples (KN2, 4, and 6). They have relatively large bending rigidities in themselves, as shown in Figure 2. The predicted bending rigidities of laminated knitted fabric with milano rib samples were much smaller than those of the experimental ones. The predicted bending rigidities of laminated knitted fabric with KN1, 3, and 5 were closer to the experimental ones than were the laminated knitted fabric with milano rib samples, KN 2, 4, and 6. However, even though the predicted results of laminated knitted fabric with KN2, 4, and 6 (MAPE 15.0%) showed a closer agreement with experimental ones than did the laminated knitted fabric with milano rib samples (MAPE 31.6%), this still resulted in large prediction errors (MAPE 19.1%). The reason for the disagreement in laminated knitted fabric with milano rib samples is the difference between the elastic modulus in bending and tensile and in-plane compressive moduli, or the placement of neutral axes in the knitted fabrics. This will be discussed in the sections on Methods 2 and 3. Due to the large prediction errors, it was found that Method 1 is not suitable for predicting bending rigidities of laminated knitted fabrics. Figure 4.

sec.title: Method 2
sec.p:
In Method 2, aparent in-plane compressive modulus and tensile modulus were taken into account based on Method 1. In addition to the bending rigidity and thickness, the apparent in-plane compressive modulus of interlining T1 and tensile modulus of face fabric T2 are necessary to calculate the bending rigidities of laminated fabrics in Method 2. T2 were obtained from the tensile properties of pressed knitted fabrics as shown in Table 4. In Method 2, if the neutral axes in bending of the components are in the centroid, T1 can be obtained using equation (3). However, the placements of the neutral axes for knitted fabrics are uncertain. Thus, the placements of knitted fabrics were investigated. The obtained T1 values using equation (3) with the bending rigidities and thicknesses of the knitted fabrics were compared with the obtained T1 values for N1 and N2. A comparison of the average of T1 values with knitted fabrics and twill fabrics by equation (3) is shown in Figure 5. If the neutral axes in bending of knitted fabrics are in the centroid, the T1 values will be the same as the T1 values from the tests with twill fabrics. However, the averages were significantly different when compared to those from twill fabrics. The variations in T1 values for the knitted fabrics were also large. Therefore, it was found that the neutral axes in bending of the knitted fabric samples are not in the centroid. The position of the neutral axes in bending of the knitted fabrics will be discussed in the section on Method 3. Therefore, T1 values from twill fabrics were used in Method 2. With the resulting bending rigidities, thicknesses, and T1 and T2 values of pressed samples, the bending rigidities of laminated fabrics were calculated (Figure 6). The MAPEs between calculated and experimental bending rigidities are shown in Table 5. As shown in Figure 6 and its MAPEs, the calculated bending rigidities of laminated knitted fabrics did not correlate with the experimental ones. Figure 5.
Comparison of average T1 values of interlinings from tests with twill fabrics and knitted fabrics.
Figure 6.
Calculated and experimental bending rigidities of laminated knitted fabrics using Method 2.

The reason for the disagreements between predicted and experimental bending rigidities using Method 2 is the position of the neutral axes in bending of face fabrics. As mentioned previously, the neutral axes in bending of knitted fabrics were not in the centroids. When the neutral axes in bending of components are not in the centroid, it is necessary to consider Y2. Therefore, it was found that Method 2 is not suitable for predicting bending rigidities of laminated knitted fabrics.

sec.title: Method 3
sec.p:
The relative position of the neutral axes in bending was taken into account for Method 3 in addition to Method 2. Y2 is necessary to predict bending rigidity of laminated knitted fabric for Method 3. The averages of Y2 for face fabrics were obtained from composites with different adhesive interlinings as shown in Figure 7. Y2 close to 0 means that the neutral axis in bending is close to the bottom of a face fabric. On the other hand, Y2 close to 1 means that the neutral axis in bending is close to the top of a face fabric. Y2 close to 0.5 means that the neutral axis in bending is close to the centroid. As shown in Figure 7, it was found that Y2 of most knitted fabrics do not lie in the centroid. Figure 7.
Average Y2 values of knitted fabrics and Y2 of composites with CE1 interlining.

Y2 values obtained using the data from laminated fabric with CE1 interlining (Figure 7) were arbitrarily selected for calculating bending rigidities of laminated knitted fabric. The calculated and experimental bending rigidities of laminated knitted fabrics using Method 3 are shown in Figure 8. The MAPEs between calculated and experimental bending rigidity are shown in Table 5. The predicted bending rigidities show good agreements with experimental ones. Especially, the calculated bending rigidities of laminated knitted fabric with milano rib samples using Method 3 show good agreements with the experimental ones. These results show that Y2 values for knitted fabrics are not in the centroid and must be taken into account to calculate the bending rigidity of laminated fabrics with knitted fabrics. Figure 8.
Calculated and experimental bending rigidities of laminated knitted fabrics using Method 3.

sec.title: Comparison of the three methods
sec.p:
Comparisons of calculated and experimental bending rigidities of laminated knitted fabrics using the three methods are shown in Figure 9. Among the predicted bending rigidities using the three methods, the results of Method 3 show the closest correlation to the experimental ones, as shown by its MAPE, 6.9%. Figure 9.
Calculated and experimental bending rigidities of laminated knitted fabrics using the three methods.

For all samples, Method 2 shows the largest MAPE, over 35%. Method 1 also shows a relatively large MAPE, over 19%. As mentioned above, especially for the milano rib samples, results using Methods 1 and 2 show large MAPEs. This is because the tensile and in-plane compressive moduli of knitted fabric are significantly different so it is necessary to consider them. According to these results, it became clear that Methods 1 and 2 are difficult to use to predict bending rigidity of laminated knitted fabrics.

In the case of woven fabric, the calculated results for some face fabric using Method 2 showed good agreement with experimental ones.2 For the samples with large prediction errors using Method 2, the calculated results using Method 3 showed better agreements with the experimental results than those using Method 2.3 However, for knitted fabrics, the calculated results using Method 2 still show large prediction errors for all samples in this study. These results show that knitted fabrics are affected more by the position of the neutral axis, so the results using Method 2 have large prediction errors. Accordingly, the position of the neutral axis for knitted fabric must be considered to calculate the bending rigidity of a laminated fabric.
In conclusion, it was found that Method 3 is the most suitable method to calculate precisely the bending rigidities of laminated fabrics with knitted fabrics.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Bending rigidities of laminated knitted fabrics with adhesive interlinings were calculated using three prediction methods with mechanical properties of components such as h1, h2, B1, B2, T1, T2, and Y2. The predicted bending rigidity of laminated knitted fabrics using both Methods 1 and 2 show large prediction errors. The predicted results using Method 3, which considers Y2, show a strong correlation with the experimental ones compared to those predicted by the other methods.

Therefore, it was found that the disagreement in the results using Methods 1 and 2 was due to the position of the neutral axis. With these results, it became clear that Y2 of a knitted fabric must be taken into account to predict the bending rigidity of laminated knitted fabrics more precisely. A suitable adhesive interlining for a knitted fabric can be selected using Method 3. Until now, the selection of adhesive interlining was carried out based on experiments and previous data. If the data concerning adhesive interlinings and face fabrics are compiled once, the prediction of the performance of laminated fabrics made of different combinations will be possible. Designers and manufacturers will be able to reduce the cost and time for selecting a suitable adhesive interlining.
